Figure 1 Figure 2 X-ray diffractograms of the ChiXCu catalysts pyrolyzed at 500 °C under a N2 flow. Figure 2 Figure 3 TEM micrographs of Chi05Cu (A), Chi30Cu (B) and Chi40Cu catalysts (C) pyrolyzed at 500 °C under a N2 flow. Figure 3 Figure 4 N2 adsorption-desorption at -196 °C (A) and CO2 adsorption at 25 °C (B) of the ChiXCu catalysts pyrolyzed at 500 °C under a N2 flow. Figure 4 Figure 5 Cu 2p core level spectra (A) and the Auger CuLMM line (B) of the ChiXCu catalysts pyrolyzed at 500 °C under a N2 flow. Figure 5 Figure 6 FUR conversion (A), FOL yield (B), MF yield (C) as a function of TOS for the ChiXCu catalysts pyrolyzed at 500 °C under a N2 flow, and comparison of the FUR conversion as a function of the Cu content after 1 h of reaction at 190 °C (D). (Experimental conditions: mcat= 75 mg, T= 190 °C, H2 flow= 10 mL min−1, feed flow= 1.94 mmol FUR h−1). Figure 6 Figure 7 XRD of the Chi30Cu pyrolyzed at 500 °C under a N2 flow, before and after the catalytic test, and Chi30Cu pyrolyzed at 700 °C under a N2 flow (A). CuLMM Auger line of the Chi30Cu pyrolyzed at 500 °C under a N2 flow, before and after the catalytic test (B). Chitosan has been used in the synthesis of catalysts for the furfural hydrogenation to obtain furfuryl alcohol. Cu-based catalysts supported on a carbonaceous matrix have been synthesized by complexation of Cu2+ species with the free electron pairs of the amino groups of chitosan under acid conditions, dried and subsequent pyrolysis. The catalytic behavior shows how the most active catalyst is Chi30Cu (30 wt% Cu), reaching a conversion close to 65% after 5 h at 190 °C. In all cases, a progressive deactivation is observed as a consequence of the adsorption of furfural and furfuryl alcohol on the support. With regard to the obtained products, these catalysts are selective to furfuryl alcohol, so these catalysts are environmentally sustainable and have great potential to be used in the synthesis of furfuryl alcohol as an alternative to copper chromite, which is highly toxic due to the presence of Cr species. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Chitosan Pyrolysis Porous carbon Furfural Furfuryl alcohol 1 Introduction Chitin is a biodegradable polymer with high potential for a wide range of applications in biomedicine, agriculture, materials science or water purification fields [1,2,3]. This polymer can be easily functionalized or used as chelating agent [4]. However, chitin can be N-deacetylated to yield chitosan. The free amino groups of chitosan can complex metal ions (Mn+), which is highly efficient for water purification and to treat industrial wastes [5,6]. Chitosan displays the ability to form nanometric films of chitosan-metal complexes with sub-nanometric roughness; therefore, these structures can be pyrolised at a temperature between 500-1000 °C to obtain metal nanoparticles, such as Cu or Au, dispersed on a carbonaceous film (Figure 1 ), with high potential in photochemistry [7–9], as well as in the catalysis field [10,11]. In the last decade, the scientific community has developed different catalytic processes to valorize biomass, in such a way that it can be used as an alternative and sustainable source of fossil fuels for obtaining energy and high value-added chemicals. One of the most sustainable biomass sources is lignocellulose, since it is highly available on Earth and can be selected so as not to interfere with the food supply. Lignocellulose, composed by cellulose, hemicellulose and lignin, can be treated to obtain energy, fuels and valuable products by several thermochemical processes [12]. Focusing on hemicellulose, it is mainly formed by xylans, which can be fragmented in their respective monomers by acid hydrolysis, obtaining xylose as main product, which, in turn, can be dehydrated to obtain furfural (FUR) [13,14]. After bioethanol, FUR is the second most important chemical product obtained from sugars [15], being considered as a platform molecule due to the reactivity of its functional groups, which allows obtaining a wide spectrum of valuable products by hydrogenation, oxidation, alkylation, acylation, dehydration, or ring-opening reactions [13]. In the case of FUR hydrogenation, the catalytic activity and selectivity pattern are directly related to the hydrogenating behavior of the active metal phase, as well as the nature and strength of its interaction with furfural molecules [16,17]. Thus, the active sites with higher hydrogenating capacity tend to interact with the aromatic ring and/or the carbonyl group [17]. However, the catalysts with lower hydrogenation capacity only interact with the carbonyl group, forming furfuryl alcohol (FOL) as product [17]. Traditionally, the furfural hydrogenation has been carried out using copper chromite (CuO.CuCr2O4) as catalyst. However, the toxicity of chromium species has led to the development of Cr-free catalysts. In this sense, several Cu-based catalysts without chromium, have emerged as environmentally benign catalysts for FUR hydrogenation, where Cu0 nanoparticles have been incorporated to different supports, such as SiO2 [17–20], MgO [21–25], ZnO [19,26–28], CeO2 [29,30], clay minerals [31], or activated carbons [32], reaching high conversion values, even better than those obtained with copper chromite [20]. Nonetheless, these catalysts tend to suffer deactivation due to the loss of available Cu sites by the deposition of carbonaceous deposits, or by sintering of copper nanoparticles [33]. The aim of the present research was to use a natural, inexpensive and abundant bio-polymer, like chitosan, to disperse and support Cu species, which were incorporated by complexation of Cu2+ ions with the amino groups of chitosan, to obtain films where these cations are well dispersed. Then, these films were pyrolyzed to obtain Cu-based catalysts supported on a carbonaceous material. It should be noted that the materials obtained by this synthetic strategy have hardly been used in the field of catalysis, nor in FUR valorization processes, so this work is highly novel. Considering these premises, the obtained catalysts were tested in the FUR hydrogenation in gas-phase, carrying out a detailed study of the influence of several parameters, such as the copper loading, the reaction time, the contact time and the catalyst stability. In addition, the effects of the pyrolysis temperature and the gas employed in the pyrolytic process were evaluated and then related with the catalytic behavior. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Reagents The synthesis of chitosan-based films was carried out using a commercial chitosan with low molecular weight (mol wt. 50000-190000 Da) supplied by Sigma Aldrich. Chitosan polymers were dissolved in an acetic acid (CH3COOH) aqueous solution (99-100%, VWR). The copper precursor was copper(II) nitrate trihydrate (Cu(NO3)2 ·3H2O) with a purity > 99.5% and supplied by Merck. The chemicals used in this hydrogenation reaction were furfural (99%, Sigma-Aldrich), cyclopentyl-methyl ether as solvent (99.9%, Sigma-Aldrich) and o-xylene as internal standard (99.9%, Sigma-Aldrich), while the gases used in the characterization of the catalysts and the reaction were H2 (99.999%, Air Liquide), N2 (Air Liquide 99.9999%) and He (Air Liquide 99.99%). 2.2 Synthesis of the catalysts In a typical synthesis, 4 g of chitosan were dissolved in 200 mL of distilled water and then different amounts of copper precursor (Cu(NO3)2 ·3H2O) were added to obtain solutions with a Cu content of 5-40 wt.%. In a next step, 2 mL of acetic acid were added to the mother solution to favor the dissolution of chitosan, leading to a gel, which was transferred to a crystallizer with a large surface (Figure 1). This gel was dried overnight at 40 °C, obtaining films, which were then pyrolyzed at different temperatures under different atmospheres (N2, H2 or CO2). The samples were labeled as ChiXCu, where X is the Cu incorporated (in wt. %) before the pyrolytic treatment. 2.3 Characterization of the catalysts The crystallinity of the catalysts was evaluated from their powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns, which were obtained using a PANanalytical X'Pert Pro automated diffractometer. This equipment has a Bragg–Brentano reflection configuration with a Ge(111) primary monochromator (CuKα1) and a X'Celerator detector using a step size of 2θ = 0.017° between 2θ = 10-70°. The crystallite size of the Cu-species (D) was estimated considering the Williamson-Hall equation (Equation 1) [34]: (1) B cos ( θ ) = ( K λ / D ) + ( 2 ε sin ( θ ) ) where B is the full width at half maximum (FWHM) of the XRD peaks, θ is the Bragg angle, K is the Scherrer constant, λ is the wavelength of the X-rays and ε is the lattice strain. The morphology was studied by Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM), using FEI Talos F200X equipment (Thermo Fisher Scientific). This equipment combines outstanding high-resolution S/TEM and TEM imaging with industry-leading energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) signal detection. Prior the TEM analysis, the samples were suspended in isopropyl alcohol and dropped onto a perforated nickel film grid. The textural parameters were determined from N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms at -196°C and CO2 adsorption-desorption at 0 °C. These experiments were carried out using an automatic ASAP 2020 equipment supplied by Micromeritics. Prior to adsorption, samples were outgassed at 110 °C and 10−4 mbar. The quantification of the surface was estimated from Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) equation considering a N2-cross section of 16.2 Å2. The pore volume was obtained from N2 adsorbed at P/P0 = 0.996. Surface area and micropore volume of samples were also determined by CO2 adsorption at 0 °C. The corresponding surface area (SDA) and micropore volume (Vmicro-DA) values were calculated by the Dubinin-Astakhov equation [35]. The chemical composition of the catalyst surfacewas studied by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, using a Physical Electronics PHI 5700 spectrometer with non-monochromatic Mg Kα radiation (300 W, 15 kV, 1253.6 eV) and a multi-channel detector. Spectra were registered in the constant pass energy mode at 29.35 eV, using a 720 μm diameter analysis area. Charge referencing was measured against adventitious carbon (C 1s at 284.8 eV). A PHI ACCESS ESCA-V6.0 F software package was used for acquisition and data analysis. A Shirley-type background was subtracted from the signals. All recorded spectra were always fitted using Gaussian–Lorentzian curves to determine the binding energy of the different element core levels more accurately. All samples were sealed in glass vials and stored in an inert solvent (cyclohexane) to avoid the oxidation of the Cu0 species. In addition, the sample preparation was carried out in a dry box under a N2 flow, where the solvent was evaporated before being placed in the analysis chamber. Then, the samples were directly analyzed without previous treatment. Raman analyses were carried out in micro-Raman JASCO NRS-5100 spectrometer. The instrument combines a dispersive Raman spectrometer and a confocal microscope equipped with DSF to optimize confocallity, diminishing optical aberrations and improving resolution up to 0.4 cm−1, if necessary. Calibration of the different laser lines is made with respect to silicon and detection is achieved by means of a high-resolution CCD (Charge Coupled Device). All the measurements were performed using a Nd:YAG laser with a wavelength of 532 nm with a power of 2.4-4.6 mW, acquisition time of 10 s (10 accumulations) and an objective of 100X. 13C MAS-NMR (magic angle spinning nuclear magnetic resonance) spectra were recorded at RT in an AVANCEIII HD 600 (Bruker AXS) spectrometer using a triple resonance CP-MAS probe of 3.2 mm at a spinning rate of 15 kHz. The magnetic field was 14.1 T corresponding to a 13C resonance frequency of 150.91 MHz. The 13C chemical shifts are referenced to adamantane. 13C MAS NMR spectra were recorded with 7-s delay with 1H decoupling (13C Hpdec with tppm15 decoupling sequence for C) and summing up 5000 scans. Infrared studies were carried out by attenuated total reflection (ATR) using a Golden Gate Single Reflection Diamond ATR System in a Vertex70 FT-IR spectrophotometer (Bruker). For the acquisition of the spectra, a spectral resolution of 4 cm−1 was used in the range of 4500-600 cm−1 for the ATR measurements and 7500-370 cm−1 with 64 accumulations. 2.4 Catalytic test The gas-phase hydrogenation of FUR was performed in a ¼” tubular quartz reactor, by putting the pelletized catalyst with a sieve between 325-400 μm in the middle of the reactor, between two layers of glass beads and quartz wool. Prior to the catalytic test, catalysts were reduced in situ under a H2 flow (60 mL min−1) at 300 °C for 30 min. Then, catalysts were cooled down to the selected reaction temperature under a H2 flow (10-30 mL min−1). Once the reaction temperature was reached, a flow of 1.94 mL h−1 of a furfural solution in cyclopentyl methyl ether (CPME) (2.5–7.5 vol.%) was continuously pumped by means of a Gilson 307SC piston pump (model 10SC). The furfural was dissolved in CPME to minimize the polymerization and resinification of FUR in the reactor lines. CPME was selected as solvent due to this chemical can be obtained from the biomass. In addition, CPME has emerged as promising alternative to other ether solvents due to its lower miscibility with water, higher boiling point, high stability as well as its low environmental impact [36,37]. The liquid samples were kept in sealed vials and subsequently analyzed by gas chromatography (Shimadzu GC-14B), using a flame ionization detector and a capillary column, CP Wax 52 CB. The furfural conversion and selectivity were calculated and defined as follows Equations 2-(3): (2) Conversion ( % ) = mol of furfural converted mol of furfural fed × 100 (3) Selectivity ( % ) = mol of the product mol of the furfural converted × 100 3 Characterization of the catalysts XRD patterns (Figure 2 ) of pyrolyzed Cu-chitosan, and subsequently reduced at 300 °C for 30 min under a H2 flow, show two well-defined diffraction peaks located at 2θ (°) = 43.4 and 50.3, which are ascribed to metal Cu0 (PDF N: 98-005-3756). Their intensity, as expected, increases with the copper content, but this is only observed until 20 wt.% (Chi20Cu catalyst), since samples with higher Cu loadings exhibit broad and low intense diffraction signals. The Cu crystallite sizes, determined by the Williamson-Hall equation [34], are much higher for the samples with the lowest copper contents (60 and 73 nm for Chi05Cu and Chi10Cu, respectively). Strikingly, from Chi10Cu to Chi40Cu, the increase in the Cu content gives rise to smaller metal Cu nanoparticles, with a size of 23 nm for the Chi40Cu catalyst. The morphology of the pyrolized Cu-chitosan samples was determined by TEM (Figure 3 ). The catalyst with the lowest Cu content (Chi05Cu) displays spherical particles with variable sizes, although it seems that the diameter of the particles is below 5 nm. The increase in the Cu content leads to a homogeneous distribution of spherical particles, with a diameter between 10-40 nm, while the use of a larger Cu content (Chi40Cu) generates a high proportion of spherical particles with a diameter lower than that observed for the Chi30Cu sample, although some agglomeration of Cu nanoparticles is also detected. From the micrographs, it can be concluded that the complexation of transition metal cations with chitosan and its subsequent pyrolysis seems to be an appropriate methodology to design catalysts, whose active phases are homogeneous with a narrow particle distribution. The textural parameters of Cu-chitosan samples were evaluated by N2 adsorption-desorption at -196 °C (Figure 4 A). In all cases, the specific surface area, obtained by the BET equation, can be considered as negligible, since they are below 11 m2 g−1 (Table 1 ). These data agree with those obtained from the TEM images (Figure 3), since the micrographs would indicate that the films lack porosity after the pyrolytic treatment. However, the analysis of the microporosity by CO2 adsorption (Figure 4B) shows that pyrolyzed Cu-chitosan displays a high microporosity, reaching a CO2 adsorption capacity of 1.18 mmol g−1 at 25 °C and atmospheric pressure. The high CO2 adsorption values make these materials interesting sorbents for the adsorption or selective separation of small molecules. The incorporation of increasing amounts of copper cations by complexation and its subsequent pyrolysis causes a progressive decrease in microporosity (Table 1), as can be inferred from surface area and pore volume estimated from CO2 adsorption at 0 °C. Thus, surface area decreases from 230 m2g−1 for Chi to 82 m2g−1 to Chi40Cu. These data differ to those obtained from N2 adsorption-desorption, since N2 molecules cannot access easily to micropores. The surface chemical composition of Cu-chitosan catalysts was evaluated by XPS analysis (Figure 5 and Table 2 ). In all cases, carbon is the main element on the catalyst surface (82.27-88.33%). The C 1s core level spectra show a single contribution located about 284.8 eV, which is assigned to C-C and C-H bonds. This signal was also used as reference to correct the charge of the ChiXCu catalysts. In spite of the chitosan was pyrolyzed, it is noteworthy that residual oxygen and nitrogen species remain in the carbonaceous structure yet. Thus, the O 1s core level spectra exhibit a contribution located at 531.8-532.0 eV, typical of –C-O bonds [38]. The N 1s core level spectra display two bands at 398.5-398.6 eV and 400.2-400.4 eV, which are associated to imine and amine groups on the catalyst surface [38]. Regarding Cu species, the Cu 2p core level spectra show a main signal located between 932.1 and 932.4 eV, which is due to reduced Cu species (Figure 5A). Considering that it is not feasible to discern between Cu0 and Cu+ from binding energy values, the CuLMM Auger line was also used (Figure 5B). In all cases, it is noteworthy the presence of a band located about 916.6-917.3 eV, which is associated to Cu+ species. From these data, it can be inferred that the pyrolytic process generates a sufficiently reducing environment to reduce Cu2+ to Cu+ species, as indicated previously by other authors [10,11]. CuLMM Auger data suggest that Cu2+ species complexed with the electron pair of amino groups of chitosan are reduced by the reducing environment formed in the pyrolytic process, although the atmosphere used was inert (N2). The reduction of the ChiXCu catalysts under a H2 flow at 300 °C for 30 min modifies the profile of the CuLMM Auger of all catalysts (Figure 5C), appearing a new contribution, more intense, located about 918.9 eV, which is attributed to Cu0 species [20]. The surface copper content (Table 2) increases with the loading, reaching the maximum value with the Chi30Cu catalyst. The catalyst with the largest Cu content (Chi40Cu) presents a lower surface Cu concentration, which suggests a poorer dispersion of the active phase . This fact can be ascribed to an excess of Cu2+ species incorporated may not be complexed with available amino groups of chitosan, which would indicate that these uncomplexed Cu2+ species are more susceptible to suffer agglomeration after a thermal treatment, as inferred from TEM micrographs (Figure 3C). In any case, the Cu exposed on the surface is very low in comparison with the theoretical Cu content incorporated in the synthesis step, so Cu nanoparticles must be susceptible to sintering, or can be partially covered by carbonaceous species formed during the pyrolysis stage. In order to determinate the type of carbon formed during pyrolysis, Raman studies were carried (Supplementary Information, Figure 1). The pyrolyzed chitosan displays two broad bands at 1356 and 1579 cm−1, which are ascribed to the G band related to sp2 bonding (1500-1700 cm−1) and the D band related to a bond-angle disorder in the sp2 caused by the presence of sp3 bonding, H or N (1200-1450 cm−1) [39,40], being characteristics of amorphous carbon [41]. The incorporation of Cu species does not cause any shift in the Raman spectra. This fact indicates that the presence of copper does not modify the carbon structure, although a progressive loss of the bands attributed to amorphous carbon is observed. The elucidation of the chemical composition of the carbonaceous structure was carried out from 13C MAS NMR (Supplementary Information, Figure 2). All NMR spectra present a similar profile regardless of the gas employed in the pyrolytic treatment, so all the carbons obtained must have the same chemical structure. Thus, a main band is observed at 129 ppm, which is associated to C=C double bonds in sp2-hybridized carbon domains, suggesting that these supports must have electrical conductivity [42]. In addition, another very broad band, with lesser intensity, is detected at 20 ppm, which is typical of the R2CH2 structures. Finally, a very small and noisy band is also observed between 55 and 90 ppm, that is attributed to the overlapping of C-NH-C, C-OH and C-O-C. This fact indicates that chitosan is not completely pyrolyzed, as was concluded from the XPS data (Table 2) [43]. The identification of functional groups present in chitosan, before and after pyrolysis, was carried out by FTIR-ATR (Supplementary Information, Figure 3). The chitosan spectrum shows a broad band with discernible peaks located at 3430, 3354 and 3286 cm−1, which are assigned to N-H and O-H stretching vibration modes, whereas the broadness is due to the formation of intramolecular hydrogen bonds [44]. The absorption bands at 2909 and 2866 cm−1 are due to the symmetric and asymmetric stretching modes of C-H bonds, respectively [44]. These bands were previously observed in other polysaccharides, such as glucans [45] or xylans [46]. The bands at 1423 and 1370 cm−1 are ascribed to -CH2- bending and symmetrical -CH3 deformation vibrations [44]. The band at 1146 cm−1 is assigned to the asymmetric stretching mode of the C-O-C bond, whereas those at 1049 and 1027 cm−1 are due to C-O stretching modes, and the band with a maximum at 896 cm−1 is assigned to the C-H bending out of the plane of the ring of monosaccharides [45]. Despite chitin was deacetylated, the band at 1650 cm−1 can be assigned to C=O stretching mode of N-acetyl groups. Moreover, two bands at 1316 and 1550 cm−1 can be associated to C-N stretching and N-H bending vibration mode of amide groups, thus confirming that N-deacetylation is not complete in the chitosan sample [47]. The pyrolysis of chitosan causes a decrease in intensity of the N-H and O-H stretching vibration bands, because of the polysaccharide decomposition. On the other hand, the bands located between 820 and 1720 cm−1 also disappear, arising a broad band with a maximum about 1540 cm−1, which is assigned to the -C=C- stretching mode [48], which agrees with the formation of a graphitic structure, in agreement with Raman spectroscopy (Supplementary Information, Figure 1) and 13C MAS NMR (Supplementary Information, Figure 2) data. The incorporation of Cu also originates a broad band with a maximum about 1282 cm−1, which is attributed to the typical stretching modes of CN heterocycles [49]. 4 Catalytic tests The ChiXCu catalysts were studied in the gas-phase FUR hydrogenation. In a preliminary study, the reactivity of the cyclopentyl methyl ether (CMPE), used as solvent, was evaluated under similar experimental conditions to those employed in subsequent catalytic studies. This catalytic test discards the formation of products, so CMPE can be considered as an inert solvent under the reaction conditions used in the present research work. In a first study, the influence of copper loading was evaluated (Figure 6 ). The catalytic data indicate that FUR conversion (Figure 6A) is directly related to the Cu content, increasing the FUR conversion by varying the Cu percentage from 5 to 30 wt.%, reaching the highest value close to 70%, after 5 h of TOS at 190 °C. The use of a higher Cu content (Chi40Cu) worsens the FUR conversion, with only 45% (Figure 6D). It can be inferred that the catalytic activity is directly related to the surface Cu content, as determined from XPS (Table 2). In any case, all catalysts suffer deactivation along the time-on-stream (TOS). In this sense, it has been reported in the literature that FUR and some products, as FOL, tend to interact strongly with the catalyst surface [50], so their desorption to leave the active phase available for new FUR molecules can become a challenge in the FUR hydrogenation in gas phase. The XPS analysis of catalysts (Table 2) has evidenced a small proportion of O- and N- species, which can interact with FUR and/or FOL molecules by hydrogen bonds, blocking the metallic sites involved in the FUR hydrogenation. Concerning the reaction products (Figure 6B-C), ChiXCu catalysts are only selective to FOL and MF, according with the catalytic behavior of most of Cu-based catalysts, which only interact with the carbonyl group of the furfural molecule [17]. In all cases, the main product is FOL, reaching a highest yield close to 64% after 5 h of TOS at 190 °C for the Chi30Cu catalyst, which is in the same range to those reported previously in the literature [18–21,24,26,29,33,51–66], considering that the catalyst loading employed in each catalytic test is only 75 mg. (Table 3 ). On the other hand, it should also be noted that MF is a minority product. The low proportion of MF agrees with those data reported in the literature, since MF is obtained from FOL through hydrogenolysis, which requires acid sites and small Cu nanoparticles [19]. The microporous carbon, obtained from the pyrolysis of chitosan (Figure 4B), lacks acid sites, and copper nanoparticles are bigger than those present in Cu-based catalysts with high selectivity towards MF [19,20], so it is expected that the main product was FOL. In order to evaluate the stability of the active phase, as well as the cause of the catalytic deactivation along the TOS, the catalysts were recovered after the catalytic test and kept in an inert solvent (cyclohexane) to be analyzed by XRD and XPS. The analysis of the Chi30Cu sample, as representative catalyst, by XRD (Figure 7 A) shows how the intensity of diffraction peaks ascribed to Cu0 nanoparticles are maintained, which would rule out sintering. However, it is noteworthy the arising of a new diffraction peak located about 2θ (°)= 37.0, that is assigned to Cu2O (PDF N: 01-077-0199) as a consequence of the partial oxidation of metallic Cu0. The size of the Cu2O crystallites, estimated by the Williamson-Hall method, is 5 nm, so it is smaller than that of metal Cu0 crystallites. On the other hand, the analysis of the used catalyst surface by XPS reveals a single contribution located about 932.1 eV, in its Cu 2p core level spectra, confirming that Cu species remain reduced after the catalytic test. The analysis of the CuLMM Auger region (Figure 7B) shows the coexistence of Cu0 and Cu+, as for the fresh catalysts. In the case of the catalyst with the highest FUR conversion (Chi30Cu), it can be clearly observed that the contribution ascribed to Cu+ species increases due to the partial oxidation of Cu0 nanoparticles during the catalytic test, which agrees with the data obtained from XRD (Figure 7A). Moreover, it is also noteworthy that the proportion of surface Cu species decreases after the catalytic test. In the case of the most active catalyst (Chi30Cu), the decrease is less pronounced, probably due to the higher proportion of available Cu0 sites on its surface, although the profile of the CuLMM Auger line is modified during the catalytic test, as was indicated previously. In this sense, the atomic concentrations (Table 2) indicate that the decrease in the Cu content after the catalytic test can be ascribed to the formation of carbonaceous deposits on the catalyst surface, which partially or totally block Cu sites. This descent is less pronounced in the case of the Chi30Cu catalyst, probably due to this catalyst displays a higher number of available Cu sites, leading to a higher conversion after 5 h of TOS at 190 °C (Figure 6A). However, Chi30Cu follows a deactivation pattern similar to those observed for the other ChiXCu catalysts. Focusing on the C 1s core level spectra (Figure 7C), it can be observed the appearance of new contributions associated to C-OH and C-O-C (286.2 eV) and –C=O species (287.8 eV) [20,33], thus confirming the adsorption of organic compounds, such as FUR and/or FOL, on the catalyst surface. This can be confirmed by the FTIR analysis of the Chi30Cu sample, after FUR hydrogenation at 190 °C (Figure 8 ). Its spectrum shows a broad band between 2980 and 2820 cm−1 assigned to the C-H stretching of alkanes and aldehydes. The bands located between 1615 and 1300 cm−1 are ascribed to the C=C stretching vibration of the aromatic skeleton of furan ring, whereas those at about 1210 and 1027 cm−1 can be assigned to the C-O stretching vibration of the furan ring, and C-OH groups. As Chi30Cu was the most active catalyst in the gas-phase FUR hydrogenation, this catalyst was chosen to carry out a more detailed analysis. In the next study, the influence of the reaction temperature on the catalytic performance was evaluated (Figure 9 ). The catalytic results reveal a full FUR conversion at t0, mainly at lower reaction temperatures (170 and 190 °C). However, the catalyst is susceptible to deactivate, although this deactivation is less prone as the reaction temperature increases. In this sense, high reaction temperature may favor the desorption of the carbonaceous deposits formed on the catalyst surface, which enables Cu sites to be available for new FUR molecules [44]. However, other authors have pointed out that FUR molecules tend to polymerize at high reaction temperature (T> 220 °C), which would suppose a pronounced decrease in catalytic activity [33], although, in the present work, this has not been detected even working at 230 °C. However, an increase in the reaction temperature hardly causes modifications in the selectivity pattern, being FOL the main product, attaining a maximum FOL yield close to 65% after 5 h of TOS at 190 °C (Figures 9B-C). Previous works have reported that FOL is the main product at low reaction temperature (170-190 °C), while MF, the hydrogenolysis product, is favored at higher reaction temperature [19,20]. Considering that the hydrogenolysis reaction requires acid sites and that the pyrolyzed chitosan hardly possesses this type of sites [19], it is expected that the main product must be FOL regardless of the reaction temperature. In addition, the influence of the pyrolysis temperature was evaluated for the Chi30Cu catalyst (Figure 10 ). The catalytic data show that the use of a higher pyrolysis temperature worsens the catalytic activity, since FUR conversion decreases from 67.8 to 20.1 %, after 5 h of TOS at 190ºC, by raising the temperature of Chi30Cu treatment from 500 to 700 °C (Figure 10A). Regarding the obtained products (Figure 10B-C), in both cases, the main product is FOL, being MF negligible, so the sintering of Cu nanoparticles does not modify the selectivity pattern. The XRD patterns of both catalysts (Figure 7A) show the typical diffraction peaks of metal Cu0 crystallites, although these diffraction peaks are more intense in the case of the sample pyrolyzed at 700 °C, which implies the formation of bigger Cu nanoparticles (109 nm) and, therefore, a lower amount of available Cu sites, decreasing FUR hydrogenation. The effect of the atmosphere used in the pyrolytic process was also studied (Figure 11 ). The catalytic data show how the use of H2 in the pyrolysis of the Cu-chitosan provokes a slight decrease in FUR conversion, although its deactivation along the TOS displays a similar profile to that shown when the Cu-chitosan was pyrolyzed under N2. The XRD analysis reveals an increase in the size of Cu0 crystallites when the Cu-chitosan was treated under H2, which decreases the amount of available metal sites, and consequently a slight decrease in catalytic activity, attaining a FUR conversion of 60%, with a FOL yield of 51%, after 5 h of TOS at 190 °C. In an additional study, Cu-chitosan was also pyrolyzed using other gases (Figure 11). Thus, under a CO2 flow, which is slightly oxidizing, the porosity of catalysts could increase, favoring the access and the diffusion of FUR molecules and the obtained products in the catalyst structure. Unfortunately, the pyrolysis of Cu-chitosan in a CO2 flow causes a drastic decrease in catalytic activity, achieving a FUR conversion of only 20%, with a FOL yield of 18%, after 5 h of TOS at 190 °C (Figure 11A). Despite the modification of the gas used in the pyrolytic treatment has a clear influence on the FUR conversion, the selectivity pattern is hardly affected (Figure 11B-C). The XRD patterns of these catalysts only show diffraction signals attributed to Cu0 crystallites (Figure 11D). However, the intensity of these peaks differs between them, since they are more intense when a H2 flow is used in the pyrolysis step, while the signals are weaker when CO2 was employed. Thus, the use of a H2 flow in the pyrolysis leads to bigger Cu nanoparticles (60 nm), which must display a lower amount of available active sites for FUR hydrogenation. This fact supposes a decrease in the catalytic activity in comparison to the catalyst synthesized using N2 in the pyrolysis step. In the case of the catalyst synthesized using CO2, the lower intensity of the diffraction peaks ascribed to Cu0 crystallites confirms the presence of smaller metallic particles (28 nm). The CuLMM Auger line of these catalysts also displays the coexistence of Cu0 and Cu+ species, in all cases (Figure 11E). The catalysts treated with N2 or H2 show how the main oxidation state is Cu0, while for the Chi30Cu catalyst treated with CO2 is Cu+. Thereby, the lower amount of copper on the catalyst surface, together with the greater proportion of Cu+ species, can be the cause of the lower catalytic activity of the Chi30Cu catalyst obtained by pyrolysis in CO2. On the other hand, the characterization of the Chi30Cu catalysts by ATR and 13C MAS NMR has not shown clear differences regarding the carbonaceous structure obtained when the pyrolysis was carried out in N2, H2 or CO2 (Supplementary Information, Figure 1-2). The XRD patterns of used catalysts reveal that the intensity of diffraction peaks associated to Cu0 crystallites is maintained, so their sintering must be discarded (Figure 11D). However, all catalysts show a broad band, which is typical of Cu2O, obtained by oxidation of Cu0 species. As the most effective catalyst was synthesized using N2 flow and a temperature of 500 °C, Chi30Cu catalyst was considered to evaluate the influence of other catalytic parameters. Thus, both the FUR fed and H2 flow were modified to maintain the same H2/FUR molar ratio in all tests (Figure 12 ). An increase in FUR fed and H2 flow, that is, a short contact time between FUR and active sites, causes a decrease in the conversion values, from 68 to only 20% when the FUR and H2 fed are tripled. That means that, as expected, a shorter contact time does not favor FUR conversion in the gas-phase FUR hydrogenation. The selectivity pattern follows the same trend to that observed in previous tests, since FOL is the main product, and the MF formation is practically negligible in all cases. 5 Conclusions Cu-based catalysts have been synthesized by the complexation of Cu2+ with amino groups of chitosan and subsequent pyrolysis to obtain microporous materials, where spherical Cu0 nanoparticles are dispersed on a carbonaceous matrix. The catalytic study of ChiXCu catalysts in the FUR hydrogenation in gas-phase has revealed that Chi30Cu catalyst is the most active catalyst, with almost full conversion after 1 h of TOS at 190 °C. However, all catalysts are prone to suffer a progressive deactivation, decreasing conversion until 64% after 5 h of TOS. The characterization of catalysts. after the catalytic tests, suggested that the deactivation can be ascribed to the strong interaction of the FUR and FOL with active sites, as well as to a partial oxidation of Cu0 species along the catalytic test. With regard to the obtained products, it is noteworthy that ChiXCu catalysts are highly selective towards FOL, while MF appears in a minor proportion. This implies that these catalysts are hydrogenating (FUR→FOL), while the hydrogenolysis reaction (FOL→MF) is hardly favored. Credit author statement A. coredata.dc:description: Chitosan has been used in the synthesis of catalysts for the furfural hydrogenation to obtain furfuryl alcohol. Cu-based catalysts supported on a carbonaceous matrix have been synthesized by complexation of Cu2+ species with the free electron pairs of the amino groups of chitosan under acid conditions, dried and subsequent pyrolysis. The catalytic behavior shows how the most active catalyst is Chi30Cu (30 wt% Cu), reaching a conversion close to 65% after 5 h at 190 °C. In all cases, a progressive deactivation is observed as a consequence of the adsorption of furfural and furfuryl alcohol on the support. With regard to the obtained products, these catalysts are selective to furfuryl alcohol, so these catalysts are environmentally sustainable and have great potential to be used in the synthesis of furfuryl alcohol as an alternative to copper chromite, which is highly toxic due to the presence of Cr species.
coredata.dc:title: Synthesis of catalysts by pyrolysis of Cu-chitosan complexes and their evaluation in the hydrogenation of furfural to value-added products
